children.value: These are synonymous with Credentials.  In uPort attestations are cryptographically signed claims.
Just like a user has a uPort identity, applications and dApps that interact with uPort users need their own identity
A claim is a record of an attestation that has been verified.

Credentials are pieces of information about a uPort user that may be requested and/or verified by applications.  They are, in their essence, signed claims that are stored with the uPort user's profile.
Distributed Application, generally one that relies on serverless architectures.
Decentralized Identifier used to retrieve a DID document as defined by the
A DID document contains public keys and other information about the DID that is used to verify interactions with a DID.  To see one implementation of how uPort resolves a DID document, see our
library.  Other types of DID resolvers offered by uPort:
A library that provides a simple interface to resolve DID documents from a decentralized identifier.
A smart contract that manages the storage of claims (attestations) made by identities and other smart contracts on the Ethereum blockchain.
The EthrDid library allows you to create Decentralized Identifiers and manage their interactions in your own app.
A smart contract that enables the resolution and management of decentralized identifiers (DIDs)
A library that takes an Ethereum address as a decentralized identifier and wraps it in a DID document and also supports key management

An identity in uPort is really just someone or something that can sign data or transactions and also receive signed data about itself.  Essentially it is an address on a decentralized network, controlled by a private signing key
A reference to the identity of an application or user that issued a signed JWT
A way without a Proxy contract to create, update, and recover uPort identities in addition to encryption and decryption of data related to the identity
A DID resolver for muPort/SimpleID resolution with support for creating identities.
Public Key Infrastructure.  uPort implements a simple PKI to verify off-chain messages
Used to verify privately signed data
Used to sign data and transactions
A 12-word passphrase used to retrieve the private keys of an Identity
A DID resolver that uses secp256k1 public keys as decentralized identifiers, as opposed to an Ethereum address.
The user selective discloses information about themselves based on a signed request.
An Ethereum account specifically used for interactions between your app and your user. It is called
because for privacy reasons it segregates the transactions to a single app, making it harder to correlate who the user is for external parties.
The act of using a private key to sign data and transactions.
Also referred to as a Private key
Ethereum test networks used by developers for testing out their applications. uPort supports both the
A driver implemented as a docker image that wraps all uPort resolvers for use in the Decentralized Identity Foundation's
A library that facilitates the resolution of legacy uPort DID documents
Can be a reference to distributed application architectures, but also
A cryptographically signed claim by one party about another party.  Synonymous with Credentials.
